remarks:
2017-Aug-08 11:47:15 by jfrey:
The job_queue.log contained 16 invalid lines, written over the course of 12 minutes. All of the lines appear to be incomplete entries that are missing a variable number of their initial characters.

2017-Aug-08 11:55:32 by jfrey:
When the schedd first opens the job_queue.log file (LoadClassAdLog()), it does not use O_APPEND. When the schedd opens a new file for truncation (TruncateClassAdLog()), it does use O_APPEND. If the file is "clean" when initially read in (i.e. no transactions and no incomplete entries), the schedd will use the non-append file descriptor for further writes. If the file isn't "clean", then it immediately does a truncation (resulting in a file descriptor in append mode).

The corruption we're seeing could be explained by a forked child process writing to the log file in non-append mode. Always opening the file in append mode would help prevent this, but we should also understand how the extra writes are happening.

2017-Aug-10 12:55:08 by jfrey:
The log corruption appears to be caused by valgrind. I wrote a simple program that called fopen(), fprintf(), and _exit(). When I run it normally, the file is empty. When I run it under valgrind, the file contains the text from my fprintf().

The corruption always occurs around updates of LastRejMatchTime and LastRejMatchReason, which are done non-durable, which means they aren't fflush()d. The corrupted job_queue.log was generated while the schedd was run under valgrind (while Greg investigated a crash). Throughout the file, groups of updates to LastRejMatchTime and LastRejMatchReason are duplicated, sometimes jumping backward in time (duplicating entries from a second ago).

I believe whenever the schedd forked a child helper process when ad updates were buffered by stdio, valgrind caused those updates to be flushed when the child process exited.
